div.p:
Praeterea considerandum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 28, xxx
. This is distinction 28 in which, after the Master treated about proper properties, now he intends to speak about some other things. And it is divided into two parts according to the two properties that he posits, therefore in the first place he treats the first, and in the second place about the second at the beginning of distinction 29,
praeterea aliud nomen
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 29
. The first part is divided into three because in the first place he treats about the property of being unbegotten, in the second place about the condition of being begotten, and in the third place .... The second begins at
illud etiam taceri non oportet
Lombardus, Sent. XXX . The third begins at
sciendum quoque
Lombardus, Sent. XXX
.

The second principal part, in which the Master treats about the second property or notion which is active spirtation, is divided into three because in the first place he shows multiple meanings of principle, in the second place he offers regarding this one question or his intention, and in the third place the declaration of this. The second begins at
Omnium ergo, quae naturaliter sunt
Lombardus, Sent. I, Distinctio 29, c. 2 [n. 3]
The third at ....

Whether the Father speaking his eternal Word is able to be called the internal principle of the Word; whether the supposite speaking the eternal Word is able to be called non-impedible internal principle of the word

That not because, if there were some word in the divine, then that would either be said essentially or relatively. Not relatively because a word is an act of the intellect according to its own manifestation which is not said relatively. Again in the second place because according to
Augustine, book XV De Trinitate, in chapter 19
verbum est cum amore notitia
Augustinus, De Trinitate, IX,
. But knowledge is not said relatively, but essentially about any person, therefore. Nor should it be said that the word is said essentially because according to
Augustine, in the aforesaid book, chapter 17
in this Trinity word is only said of the son
Augustinus, XV De Trinitate, c. 29

In the second place principally thus, there are several understandings or utterances in the divine, therefore there are many words there or nothing should be put there. The consequent is false. And the consequence is clear because with respect to any utterance there is a giving of a word. The antecedent is clear through
Anselm, Monologion, chapter 62 , where he says that
every person speaks itself
Anselmus, Monologion, c. 62, xxx
.

In the third place, in the divine there is no beginning. Proof, because this would either through an internal or external relation. Not the first because the beginning and the cause are the same, as is held in
IV and V Metaphysics
Aristoteles, Metaphysicae, XXX
, but no cause should be posited in the divine through an internal relation, therefore. Nor the second because it is produced internally equally, perfectly or even more perfectly, than it is produced externally. And in the second place because then, just as three supposites produce three created things, so three principles begin three begun things, which is false. And the consequence is clear
since any of these supposites is the principle with respect to what is creatable.

On the contrary is the
Master in these distinctions
Lombardus, Sent., I, d. XXX, c. xxx
, where puts forward Augustine for his position.

First conclusion: just as the Word or Son is the operative art of omnipotence, so it is the infallible declarative knowledge of every true thing. The first part is from
Augustine, VI De Trinitate, in the last chapter , who says, the divine Word or Son of God is the art
is the art of omnipotence full of every living reason
Augustinus, De Trinitate, VI, 10, 11
. The second part is clear through
the same author in 83 questions, question 63
et
On John
in the beginning was the word Ioannes 1:1
saying
in this place the Word would be better interpreted as ratio as it signifies not only a relation to the Father, but also to those things which through the Word are made operative powers
. Again,
V De Trinitate, in chapter 5
the word is the beginning of every work
Augustine, De Trinitate, V, c. 5, xxx
.

First corollary: though the Father is said to be everything which is and which has to communicate with the Word, nevertheless the Father is able to reveal nothing to the Son or the Word itself. The first is clear through
Augustine, V De Trinitate, chapter 15, de parvis , who says,
the Son not only has itself from the Father, such that it is the Son, but also entirely, such that it is.
Augustine, De Trinitate, V, c. 15, xxx
. The second is clear because to reveal conveys imperfection because it argues that there is a non-knowing in the one who a revelation is made, therefore it ought not to be attributed to the divine Word, since it is the true art and declarative knowledge of the truth.

Second corollary: the eternal and infallible word really relate to everything possible or makeable. The opposite is held by
Scotus, distinction 27, question 3, near the end
Scotus, Sent. I, d. 27, q. 3, xxx.
. The corollary is clear through
Anselm, Monologion, in chapter 33 , where he says
by one and the same word God the Father says himself and whatever he makes
Anselmus, Monologion, c. 33
and in 34 he says
the work which he makes according to some art, not only when it was made, but before it was made, and after it is dissolved, always is in the art itself not other than what it is itself.
Anselmus, Monologion, c. 34
. This corollary is also clear from the sayings of
Saint Thomas, question 4, De Veritate, article 5
where he says
the name word is used to signify something absolute with respect to something joined
Aquinas, De Veritate, q. 4, a. 5
and below
the word principally relates to the Father, but as a consequent and as if by accident it is related to the creature
Aquinas, De Veritate, q. 4, a. 5
therefore.

Third corollary: just as every intelligible or producible thing is impressed in the Father, so every intelligible thing is expressed through the Word or in the Word. This is clear because the eternal word is not only expressed about the essence as if about an object present to the paternal intellect, but it is also expressed about every intelligibile thing. But all intelligible things are in the Father unitively impressively, therefore the divine Word is expressed about every intelligible thing.

From what has been said it is clear that besides the divine suppositional, there is not absolute or essential Word, or beyond the filial supposite, there is no divinal word. This is clear because
in the Trinity the Word is not said unless the it is the Son
Augustinus, De Trinitate, XV, c. 29
, as is clear from
Augustine 5 De Trinitate, chapter 27 .

Second conclusion: the divine Word is a singular term of paternal intellection, emanating from the one understanding by an act that remains internal and of another and declarative of itself. This conclusion is clear because, if it were not singular, it follows in the first place that paternal understanding would not have understood itself, which is false. In the second place, it follows that such a term would not have been produced from the full fecundity of understanding and from every intrinsic perfection, which is false. In the third place, it follows that such a power would not be actuated in the highest degree because such an act of understanding would be intrinsically potential, which is false.

First corollary: though something is produced externally by the same Word, nevertheless it is said that something is produced from the Word because it is not said from the Word. The first part is clear through what is said by Anselmum because
by the same word God the Father speaks himself and whatever he makes
Anselm Monologion c. 33
The second part is clear because the Holy Spirit is produced spiratively by the Word, and nevertheless the Holy Spirit is not spoken because then it would be the word of the word, against
Augustine, on John in principio.
Augustinus, XXX
.

Second corollary: only the Father produces the Word so perfectly or expresses what impresses every level of consubstantial likeness to it, or thus the divine Word exists so similarly to the one speaking that it excludes every level dissubstantial likeness. This is clear through
Anselm, Monologion 40
where from many things said he thus concludes the Word, therefore the highest of the Father
thus is similar to itself, as no offspring thus is, namely, entirely similar to its parent.
Anselm, Monologion, 40
.

Third corollary: though the Father having been produced in love is loving, nevertheless the Father having been produced or begotten in the Word is not understanding or knowing. The first is clear through what has been said and the
Master
Lombard, Sent. xx
since the Father and the Son love themselves and us through the Holy Spirit who is love produced spiratively. The second is clear because the Father knows wisdom formally unbegotten, without origin. The opposite of this second part is held by
Scotus, in distinction 27 of book one, in the third question near the end, in the solution of the third argument
Scotus, I, d. 27, q. 3
.

Third conclusion: if it is so properly received, namely for that to which another being follows, and this beginning is said to be what is produced through something, then from the Father with respect to the Son a beginning is admitted within the divine, and the name with respect to the same thing is excluded. The first part is clear because the Son truly and really is generated from the Father, therefore the Son is produced from the Father, therefore the Father is the beginning of the Son. The first consequences is clear because every generation is production, and the second consequence is clear through the acceptance of the principle posited in the conclusion. But the antecedent is a catholic truth. The second part is proved because in the divine there is nothing before or after, therefore there is nothing there to which something else follows, therefore the name of cause has not place there unless with respect to what it is creatable.

The first corollary: though from the three supposites something created is produced, nevertheless from the three uncreated principles no produced thing is co-created. This is clear through the
Master, in distinction 29 , where he says,
the Father, Son, and Holy Spirit are not three principles, but one principle of all creatures because from one and the same mode the initiated things, for it is not the case that things are in one mode from the Father, and in another mode from the Son, but the are thoroughly in the same mode
.

Second corollary: it is not the case that something external is immediately caused through the will of the first principle and that the divine knowledge does not terminate to it. This is clear because, just as things are produced through the will and power of God, so they are directed by knowledge, for these are the eternal foundations of all creatures and the first principle, as says
Hugh, in I De sacramentis, part 2, in the last chapter
Hugo de Sancto Victore, De sacramentis, I, pars 2, xxx
.

Third corollary: thought God the Father alone is not able to create anything, nevertheless he is able to begin something. The first part is clear because whatever is an external creatable thing is producible by the three divine supposites. The second part is clear because the Father alone begins the Son through the mode of understanding, therefore.
From all of these things, the affirmative part of the conclusion follows.

Contra primam conclusionem, arguitur quia Filius est eo verbum quo Filius et eo Filius quo verbum, sed Filius ut Filius divinius non dicit potentiam operativam nec artem declarativam ergo nec verbum, et per consequens conclusio falsa.

Contra secundum corollarium, si verbum referretur ad creaturam et ad Patrem vel uno respectu seu eadem relatione vel diversis si 2m sequitur quod duo distincti relatus quia respectu cuiuslibet possibilis habebit distinctum relatum quod non videtur nec primum quia relatus verbi ad patrem est actualis relatus vero quem habet ad possibilia est habitualis solum ergo.

Tertio, contra tertium corollarium, si verbum exprimitur etc. vel ergo aeque primo exprimitur de divina essentia, sicut de aliis intelligentibus vel secundum prius et posterius. Si primum sequitur quo aeque primo divinus in
tellectus beatifice intuetur pro obiecto quaecumque intellecta, sicut essentiam divinam quod non videtur verum si detur. Secundum, sequitur quod in divinis erit prioritas et posterioritas quod supra fuit negatum.

Quarto, contra sub corollarium arguitur sic ex dicto Basili super illo verbo Ad Hebraeos primo
portans omnia verbo virtutis suae Hebraeos 1:3
ubi dicit quod Spiritus Sanctus est verbum Filii.

Contra secundam conclusionem: arguitur per
Anselmum Monologion 40
dicentem quod
rem cogitare cuius memoriam habemus hoc est in mente eam dicere
sed in Deo sunt plura dicere, ergo plures sunt ibi termini intellectuales.

Secundo contra eandem et corollarium: illud est verbum interius manens quod per se, et primo significatur per verbum exterius, sed quidditas rei ut intellecta per verbum exterius significatur, ergo res intellecta est verbum interius, sed talis res non emanat ab intelligente
ergo
ergo

Tertio contra tertium corollarium, intellectio formaliter est in Patre, ergo et verbum, et per consequens intelligit intellectione genita quod est oppositum corollarii. Antecedens patet et probatur consequentia quia quam formaliter competit amor volitioni tam formaliter competit verbum intellectioni sed adintra volitio non est sine amore, ergo nec intellectio sine verbo genito.

Contra tertiam conclusionem, arguitur per
Damascenum libro primo capitulo 2
ubi dicit quod
pater est causa filii ergo in divinis est nomen causae concedendum
Ioannes Damascenus, De fide orthodoxa, I, c. 2, xxx
.

Secundo, si nomen principii dicitur in divinis per relatum adextra et adintra vel ergo aeque primo vel non. Non primum quia tunc diceretur univoce adintra et adextra nec prius adintra quam adextra cum adintra notionaliter dicatur adextra vero essentialiter nec prius adextra quam adintra cum adintra dicatur aeternaliter.

Tertio contra corollarium, responsivum si Pater est principium verbi geniti et entis producti aut aequaliter est principium illorum aut aliter et aliter non aequaliter quia adextra est sic principium quod eam etiam entis procreati nec aliter et aliter quia tam creatura quam verbum procedunt per modum intellectus, ergo eodem modo. Consequentia tenet et antecedens patet quia creaturae procedunt a Deo sicut artificatum ab arte, sed hoc est per modum intellectus procedere.

Ad primam, dicitur quod Filius est ars Patris declarativa, licet non appareat in hoc nomine Filius. Unde
Anselmus
quando dicit
eo verbum quod Filius Anselmus, XXX
et econverso vult dicere quod sicut in divinis filius dicitur notionaliter ita verbum.

Ad secundam, dicitur quod eadem relatione refertur ad utrumque, non tamen sequitur quod creatura sit aeterna vel quod verbum divinum sit verbum creaturae sic quod creatura dicit ipsum verbum, sed potest dici verbum creaturae sic quia ipsa dicitur aeternaliter per ipsam. Secundo dico et est quasi id quod verbum divinum non debet dici verbum creaturae active sic quod dicat ipsum sed bene passive eo quia creatura dicitur per ipsum.
Ad tertiam, dicitur quod aeque primo quia in Patre est unica ratio intelligendi et essendi nec est ibi aliqua diversitas vel prioritas ex parte rei.

Ad quartam, dicitur quod Basilius et alii Graecorum doctores usi sunt nomine verbi et imaginis pro omni eo quod procedit in divinis et sic Spiritus Sanctus potest dici verbum, sed tamen proprie nomen verbi dicitur solum de eo quod procedit ab intellectu, ideo Basilius sint figurative et improprie ibi verbum.

Ad primam contra secundam conclusionem, dicitur quod non quodlibet dicere vel intelligere large loquendo habet termen ut supra patuit
distinctio 6
Lombardus, Sent. I, xxx
. Hoc etiam tenet
Scotus, libro primo, distinctio 32
Scotus I, d. 32
.

Ad secundam, dicitur primo quod res intellecta non est verbum sed potius aliquod productum ex intentione quia verbum relinquitur in intellectu. Secundo dicitur quod nomina intellectum rei significant secundario.

Ad tertiam, negatur consequentia, et ad probationem quando dicitur quia ad intra non est volitio
non est sine amore dicitur quod si li est sit copulativa vel nota originis et non formalitatis conceditur, et sic non est contra dicta. Secundo, dico quod sumendo large amorem concedi potest quod volitio est amor productus vel producens, non tamen oportet quod sit productus per illud id suppositum quod est amor. Unde Spiritus Sanctus est amor productus, non tamen per amorem quod personaliter est Spiritus Sanctus et est quod dico volitio in divinis.

Et si obicitur contra corollarium et responsionem quod sequitur plures esse sapientias in divinis quia Pater est sapiens sapientia non genita et Filius sapientia genita. Hic negatur consequentia quia non plus valet quam illa Deus est genitus et Deus est non genitus, ergo sunt plures dii. Patet quod haec non valet sic nec prima.
Ad primam contra tertiam conclusionem hic dicitur quod graeci utuntur aliter hoc nomine causa quam nos, ideo Damascenus loquitur ibi ad modum Graecorum.

Ad secundam, primo posset dici secundum
Thomam Argentia Thomas Argentia, XXX
quod principium convenit Deo prius per comparationem et relatum adintra quam adextra quia emanatio divinarum personarum est ratio emanationis creaturarum et per consequens prior. Secundo, dicitur secundum eundem ibidem quod principium in divinis secundum relatum[?] creaturarum intrinsece et respectu creatorum extrinsece non dicitur univoce nec aequivoce, sed analogice tum quia relatus[?] quem habet adintra ponit aliquid reale sed relatus adextra non semper ponit aliquid reale. Tertio, dico quod non quodlibet essentiale semper est prius quodlibet notionali.

Ad tertiam, dicitur quod non aequaliter nec eodem modo, et ad probationem negatur consequentia quia, licet emanatio utriusque sit secundum intellectum, non tamen secundum eandem rationem praecise nec eodem modo. Item posset dici quod creaturae emanant a Deo libere et per modi voluntatis verbum vero per modum intellectus.

Ad primam, dicitur in oppositum quod relative verbum dicitur et ad probationem bene conceditur illud assumptum, sed tamen illa non est completa et sufficiens ratio verbi, et ideo nihil concludit similiter dicitur ad Augustinum quod ex scientia verbum gignitur, sed tamen non est praecisa ratio verbi.
Ad secundam, negatur consequentia quia non quodlibet dicere vel intelligere habet termen productum.

Ad tertiam, negatur consequentia. Et cum ultra arguitur quod si esset principium per relatum[?] adextra etc., hoc negatur sed tantum unum est principium producens creaturam prout Magister docet in hac distinctione.

Praeterea considerandum est
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 28, xxx
. Prima conclusio 28 distinctionis: quod ingenitus relative dicitur de Patre et dicitur ingenitus secundum proprietatem generationis et dicitur relative quia non dicitur secundum substantiam quod enim relative pronunciatur non indicat substantiam, licet ergo genitus et ingenitus diversum sit, non tamen indicat diversam substantiam.
Secunda conclusio: quod Spiritus Sanctus potest dici non genitus, licet proprie non dicatur ingenitus quia ingenitus dicitur secundum notionem innascibilitatis et originis.

Tertia conclusio: quod
spiritus sanctus
Ambrosius noluit beati isto termino ingenitus propter haereticos Arrianos sic etiam non oportet subticere quemdam propter calumniatum insidias.

Quarta, conclusio quod diversum est esse Patrem, et Filium, Spiritum Sanctum quia non ea notione Pater est Pater quam Filius est Filius vel Spiritus Sanctus est Spiritus
est spiritus
Sanctus.

Quinta conclusio: quod non est aliud Patrem esse et aliud Filium esse, licet aliud sit esse Patrem posito li patrem a parte praedicati quia esset dicere quod aliud est quo Pater est et aliud quo Filius est quod est omnino falsum.

Sexta conclusio: licet diversum sit esse Patrem et esse Filium, non tamen est diversa substantia quia haec non secundum substantiam
dicuntur sed secundum relationem quod tamen relatum non est accidens quia non est mutabile.

Septima conclusio: sicut solus Filius dicitur verbum et imago, ita etiam solus dicitur sapientia nata vel genita et in hoc quod dicitur nata intelligitur notio eadem quae nominatur quando dicitur verbum vel imago. Cum autem dicitur sapientia nominatur essentia non quod essentia sit nata sed intellectus est quod Filius sit genitus qui est essentia vel accipitur ibi essentia pro hypostasi, unde sapientia nata est hypostasis genita.

Octava conclusio quod imago quandoque relative dicitur sicut verbum et Filius quandoque essentiam significat, et tunc ad se dicitur et non relative et secundum hoc dicit
Hilarius Hilarius de Poitiers, xxx
quod homo fit ad communem imaginem trinitatis. Et haec de distinctione.

Est praeterea considerandum
Lombardus, Sent. I, d. 29
. Prima conclusio distinctionis 29 quod principium in divinis dicitur relative. Pater enim est principium non de principio Filius principium de principio et Spiritus Sanctus principium de utroque, scilicet de Patre et Filio.

Secunda conclusio: quod Pater dicitur principium totius deitatis se divinitatis non quod sit principium essentiae divinae sed quia est principium filii et Spiritus Sancti
in
in
quibus singulis est tota deitas seu tota essentia.

Tertia conclusio: quod Pater est ab aeterno principium Filii et Pater et Filius non sunt duo principia, sed unum principium Spiritus Sancti, Pater enim non est paternitate principium Spiritus Sancti nec Filius filatione, sed Pater et Filius una et eadem notione sunt unum principium Spiritus Sancti et illa notio est activa spiratio.
Quarta conclusio: quod licet Spiritus Sanctus sit ab aeterno seu aeternaliter, non tamen est principium ab aeterno quia non dicitur principium nisi respectu creaturarum quae non fuerunt ab aeterno.
Quinta conclusio: quod non solum Spiritus Sanctus est principium creaturarum, sed Pater et Filius, et hi tres non sunt tria principia, sed unum omnium creaturarum principium.
Sexta conclusio: quod Pater dicitur principium Filii quia genuit ipsum et Pater et Filius sunt unum Spiritus Sancti principium quia Spiritus Sanctus ab utroque procedit.

Septima conclusio: sicut Pater et Filius ad creaturam dicunt relative unus creator unus dicens dicitur sic relative ad Spiritum Sanctum unum principium sunt vel dicuntur ad creaturam vero Pater, Filius et Spiritus Sanctus unum principium est sicut unus creator et unus dominus.
Octava conclusio: licet Filius sit principium de principio, tamen non est concedendum quod Filius habeat principium suae durationis quamvis habeat principium originis.

Nona conclusio: quod Pater et Filius eadem notione seu relatione dicuntur principium Spiritus Sancti, illius autem notionis quod ibi notat principium nomen non habemus nec est ipsa paternitas vel filiatio sed est quaedam notio quae est Patris et Filii qua ab aeterno Pater et Filius unum principium sunt sancti sequitur distinctio 30.
